I have an input pattern and an output pattern both with random data 
set, =
my goal then is to form an ANN which can reponse to the input 
pattern by y=
ielding the output pattern as precisely as possible. Of 
course this is don=
e by NEAT.
When the error limit I preset was somewhat bigger say 0.1, the 
=
program worked well, and gave results very quickly. But when I 
improved th=
e limit to be 0.01 or even smaller, the program became 
unbearably slow, wh=
ile the fitness curve was not as I had expected 
but to go down and down th=
rough, and finally fluctuated near a value 
far from optimum.
I am using MA=
TLAB_NEAT, by modifying the XOR_EXPERIMENT. I have 
changed the fitness fun=
ction to 1/(1+rmse)(Thanks to Emyr James), 
where rmse is the root mean squ=
are error which measures the agreement 
of output with output pattern, it i=
s computed by concerning every row 
of the output, just as the original pro=
gram does. The program uses 
sigmoidal function as its activation function.=
 In my first several 
experiments, I forgot to modify the gain scale factor=
, which was 4.9 
originally, surely to be in favour of classification, but =
not proper 
in an output pattern randomly distributed between -1 and 1. Aft=
er 
having studied the possible weights, I used 0.84 as the gain scale 
fac=
tor. Of course I had scaled the sigmoidal function outputs to be  
[-1,1](T=
hanks to Stephen Waits).
Have I forgotten something? Until now I have mainl=
y experimented 
under one-column output, even this will take hundreds of ge=
nerations, 
but only to find stuck in the end, and this happens when I have=
 just 
changed the error limit from 0.1 to 0.01. Is that common? I have als=
o 
tried the intended three-column output pattern several times, but the 
r=
esults were terrible, maybe require thousands of generations to get 
an ans=
wer, or maybe not.
I have read through Ken's doctoral paper, but it's too a=
bstract, and 
I found no solution to what I have encountered. Actually the =
problem 
I am working on has already been resolved by BP network, with 28 
=
hidden nodes. I only want to find a simpler and more efficient 
network, so=
 I turned to NEAT.
But now I can go no further, could you tell me why? Mayb=
e the 
original code of XOR_EXPERIMENT is basically unable to solve a 
prob=
lem other than classification? Or have I messed up something?
